questionListItems.title: Clarity needed for Gardasil 9 vaccination
questionListItems.body:
Hi,

I am 25 this year and had taken the first 2 doses of Gardasil 9 a few years ago but didn’t complete the full 3 doses. I found out that I had also previously had a complete 3 doses of the vaccine (not sure which) when I was in secondary school, thus didn’t complete the 3rd dosage of Gardasil 9 as previously mentioned.

Is it advisable to:
1) Get the 3rd dosage of Gardasil 9,
2) Restart the 3 doses of HPV vaccination, or
3) Not receive any more vaccines due to having already completed the full course in secondary school

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Thank you!

answer.body: As you have completed the full HPV vaccination course during secondary school, there is no need to take another dose. There is no requirement to stick to a specific vaccine type.

questionListItems.title: Already received gardisil 9 vaccination. Do I still need to go for cervarix vaccination?

answer.body:
If you have already completed the HPV vaccination course, there is no need to go for the HPV2 (Cervarix) dose.

For females who are 15 years old and above at the time of the first dose, a total of 3 doses are recommended. The second dose may be given between 1 and 2.5 months after the first dose, followed by the third dose between 5 and 12 months after the first dose.

For females who are 9 – 14 at the time of the first dose, a total of 2 doses are recommended. The second dose may be given 5 – 13 months after the first dose.

questionListItems.title: I might have taken HPV vaccine before when I was younger but it is not recorded in my HealthHub. Is there any harm if I take it again?

answer.body:
It would be best to seek the medical advice of a CHAS GP by booking an appointment via book.health.gov.sg. 

If you are between the age of 18-26, please refer to What is the cost of the HPV vaccination? page for more information regarding costs.
Do note that if you are above the age of 27, the GP will advise you on a suitable vaccine type and the expected unsubsidised costs.

questionListItems.title: If the HPV vaccine for 1st and 2nd jab was taken 11 months apart, does this affect chas subsides?

answer.body:
For Singapore citizen females aged 18 – 26 years, the subsidised price fee cap of HPV2 vaccination at CHAS clinics is applicable as long as the first dose is taken between your 18th birthday and before your 27th birthday. 
The subsidised price fee cap of HPV2 vaccination at CHAS clinics is also dependent on the type of CHAS card you hold.

questionListItems.title: Unsure if I have taken the HPV vaccine, if I take again, is it okay?
questionListItems.body: Hi, I'm unsure if I have taken the vaccine. I tried to look at my health hub app, I do not see that I haven taken the HPV vaccine. Will it be okay if I take the HPV vaccine 2 cycle? Incase I have really had the HPV vaccine before but is unaware of it. Thanks!

answer.body:
Singaporeans who are born in 1996 or later are able to access their vaccination records via HealthHub with their Singpass.

Those who are born earlier (i.e. before 1996) are also able to access their vaccination records via HealthHub. However, records are only available for vaccinations under the National Adult Immunisation Schedule (NAIS), which were given on or after 1 Nov 2017, and notified accordingly.

 

To view your immunisation records in HealthHub, login and click on Services > Health Records > Immunisation Records > Nationally Recommended.

 

If you have already taken two or three doses of the HPV vaccine (refer to dosage information here), there is no need to repeat the vaccination course.

If you are unsure about having taken the HPV vaccine, please book an appointment via book.health.gov.sg to receive medical advice from a GP.

Subsidy eligibility applies.

questionListItems.title: Delay in taking HPV2 dose
questionListItems.body:
I have received a message from MOH to receive the HPV2 vaccination and it mentioned that I would have to take it before my 26th birthday (in November). However, I am currently living in New York (America) and would be unlikely to take it by my birthday as I will only likely be back in December. Is there any way I can push back the deadline so I can still be subsidised?

Thank you!

answer.body:
Subsidies for Singapore citizen females aged 18 – 26 years are applicable if the first dose is taken before the 27th birthday. If you are turning 26 this Nov, and will be returning in Dec, you can still benefit from the subsidies.

However, if you are turning 27 this November, you may take the first dose in New York, and take the second and third dose in Singapore. Subsidies will only be applicable for the second and third dose taken locally and will depend on the CHAS category that you are in.

questionListItems.title: Can I pay the remaining amount for the vaccinations by cash, instead of MediSave?

answer.body: Yes. Patients can choose whether to tap on MediSave for vaccinations where MediSave use is applicable or to use cash to pay the remaining co-payment after subsidy is applied.

questionListItems.title: Can MediSave be used for the co-payment after subsidy for vaccinations?

answer.body:
Those eligible for subsidised vaccination may also use their MediSave to cover the out-of-pocket expenses at CHAS GP clinics and polyclinics.

Please check with your preferred clinic if the clinic is able to process the remaining co-payment via MediSave. If they do, please check with them on your eligibility to pay via MediSave.

questionListItems.title: Does the patient make their payment online at the Health Appointment System?

answer.body: No. The Health Appointment System will not handle any payment. The patient will pay directly at the Clinic.

questionListItems.title: Do I have to give immediate priority to a patient with an appointment?
questionListItems.body: What if my clinic is busy and I cannot see the patient immediately?

answer.body: No. There is no expectation for you to see the patient immediately at the allotted appointment time. A wait time of less than 15 minutes is reasonable.

questionListItems.title: How can I obtain a CHAS card?

answer.body:
All Singapore Citizens are eligible for CHAS. The CHAS benefits will be tiered according to household monthly income per person or the Annual Value (AV) of the home.

Additional information about how to sign up for a CHAS card and eligibility can be found here: (https://www.chas.sg/eligibility-and-application).

questionListItems.title: How do GP clinics apply to be onboard with the TF-SCS Human Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Immunisation Programme?

answer.body: You are invited to fill up (this form) to indicate your interest on coming onboard as a participating CHAS clinic offering HPV2 (Cervarix) for the TF-SCS Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Immunisation Programme and will be contacted by Singapore Cancer Society to proceed with the application process.

questionListItems.title: How much do I have to pay if I have the Public Assistance (PA) card?

answer.body:
Nationally recommended vaccinations are fully subsidised at CHAS GP clinics for those who hold the Public Assistance card.

To receive subsidies at participating CHAS GPs, Singapore Citizens on PA will need to produce their PA card and NRIC during the visit.

Patients who go to the polyclinics for their vaccination(s) and have financial difficulties in paying for their bills can approach the social worker at polyclinics to enquire for assistance.

questionListItems.title: How should I take the HPV vaccine?

answer.body:
For females aged 9 – 14 years at the time of the first dose, a total of 2 doses are recommended. The second dose may be given 5 to 13 months after the first dose.


For females aged 15 years and above at the time of the first dose, a total of 3 doses are recommended. The second dose may be given between 1 to 2.5 months after the first dose, followed by the third dose between 5 to 12 months after the first dose.


If you have taken one type of HPV vaccine for the first dose and wish to change to the other type of HPV vaccine for the second dose, it is generally fine to do so. Please discuss with your doctor about your specific situation should you wish to change vaccine type for the second or third dose.


If you have recently received the COVID-19 vaccine (e.g. in the last 14 days), you can still receive the HPV vaccine. An interval of at least 14 days before or after the COVID-19 vaccine is encouraged, but is not strictly necessary. Please consult your doctor for the latest guidelines.

questionListItems.title: I have been receiving SMS invitations for someone else. What do I do?

answer.body:
If you have been receiving SMSes that are intended for someone else, please fill up this FormSG.

You will need to copy and paste the SMS that you have received, so that we can identify and unlink the intended recipient from your contact number.

An email acknowledgement will be sent once this has been completed.
